text: hi guys it's angel
today's tip Tuesday and in this week's
homie kitchen tip I'm Shane you guys
three of my favorite tips on how to
maintain your wood cutting ports now
cutting boards are a very important
kitchen tool and I don't know about you
but I've spent a lot of money on my
cutting boards and I want them to last
forever which they will but you need to
make sure that you take care of them and
maintain them and treat them with love
so my first tip is super important if
you don't do any of these tips at least
do the first one tip number one oiling
cutting boards
I recommend oiling your cutting boards
at least quarterly if not monthly if you
have time but the reason why we want to
do that is because a cutting board that
is not oil will crack and wore over time
and in addition to that it'll start to
lose its luster and Sheen and finally if
you don't continue to oil your cutting
boards you'll start to lose that
protective layer on the top which helps
prevent it from staining and also helps
bacteria from growing in the wood very
important so to show you guys how to oil
your cutting boards properly I've got a
new cutting board which I am going to
oil I've gone ahead and washed the sport
with hot soapy water and it's fully
dried right now and I'm going to use a
little bit of coconut oil now you can
use mineral oil and that's
I used to use but I was always weirded
out about mineral oil because even
though it's food grade it still kind of
felt weird to be eating mineral oil so a
few months ago I started using coconut
oil and I find that it works so much
better it lasts longer machine on my
cutting boards are much better than
mineral oil and it's edible because I
use it for baking all the time I know
exactly what coconut oil is so highly
recommend coconut oil so what I'm going
to do is just take a little bit of
coconut oil and on a soft cloth or a
paper towel just put a little bit on
there and we're just going to buff it in
you can also just use your hands as well
and since it's coconut oil its edible
too while you're at it you can also do
the same thing for wooden spoons as well
now if you haven't done this for a while
or your board is super thirsty it might
absorb all the oils so you may need to
do a couple layers first so just keep
rubbing it in and then buffing out any
excess that there is and then when
you're done let it sit dry overnight or
let it sit out for a couple hours and
then your board is ready to go tip to
the everyday clean up this tip applies
when you're cutting things like fruits
and vegetables so I've got my butcher
block share which is super heavy and I
don't want to and I don't need to wash
it under soap and water every day so
what I'm just going to do is wipe your
cutting boards with a clean damp cloth
wipes as best as you can then with a
little bit of vinegar water I'm just
going to spray before and then give it
away clean now the great thing about
this is that if you cut things like
green onions and there's always that
residual smell vinegar water mixture
will help remove that smell and
neutralize the odors so highly recommend
vinegar water for your everyday cleanup
tip 3 the spot cleaner so if you ever
cut things like strawberries or beets
for salads on your cutting board you'll
notice that they do a really good job in
staining and if for some reason you
can't get those stains out with a little
bit of vinegar water you can always do
the natural spot cleaner which is a
slice of lemon all you need to do is
take a lemon wedge or a lemon slice
put a little bit of lemon juice on the
board rub the spot and leave it directly
on top of the spot or where the stain is
let that sit for five to ten minutes
depending on how bad the stain is and
voila the stain is gone the lemmas
assets work as a natural bleach to
remove your stains great spot remover I
hope you found today's tip Tuesday
helpful and now I have a question for
you guys how many cutting boards do you
own and how often do you all them let me
know in the comments below and I will
see you guys next time bye
